columns.name: Ticker
columns.description: Ticker for identifying a stock e.g. MSFT for Microsoft.

columns.name: SimFinId
columns.description: Unique ID for a company in the SimFin database. This is the number that is shown at the end of the URL if you visit a company profile on simfin.com

columns.name: Company Name
columns.description: Name of a company e.g. 'Microsoft'.

columns.name: IndustryId
columns.description: Industry code of company. See 'industries' dataset for details.

columns.name: Ticker
columns.description: Ticker for identifying a stock e.g. MSFT for Microsoft.

columns.name: SimFinId
columns.description: Unique ID for a company in the SimFin database. This is the number that is shown at the end of the URL if you visit a company profile on simfin.com

columns.name: Currency
columns.description: Currency for the data e.g. 'USD' for U.S. Dollar.

columns.name: Fiscal Year
columns.description: Fiscal year for a financial report. This may not equal the calendar year.

columns.name: Fiscal Period
columns.description: Fiscal period for a financial report e.g. 'Q1' for the 1st Quarter.

columns.name: Report Date
columns.description: Date that is stated in the financial report. For example, a date of 2018-12-31 means that the financial report is for the annual or quarterly period ending on that date. This is typically NOT the date that the financial report was made available to the public, see PUBLISH_DATE for that.

columns.name: Publish Date
columns.description: Date that a financial report was first made available to the public. It is possible that the financial report was later restated, in which case RESTATED_DATE will reflect that. Note that for US companies, the PUBLISH_DATE currently only uses the publication date of the Form 10-K and 10-Q for the annual and quarterly reports, and does not use the publication date of preliminary reports filed as Form 8-K. So it is possible that the information was actually made available prior to the PUBLISH_DATE in such a preliminary report.

columns.name: Restated Date
columns.description: Date when a financial report was last restated. It is possible that a financial report has been restated multiple times, in which case this is the most recent date that it was restated, and the financial data will be from the latest restatement of the financial report. If the report was never restated, then this date will be the same as PUBLISH_DATE.

columns.name: Shares (Basic)
columns.description: Shares outstanding NOT adjusted for dilution from stock-options etc. Weighted average for the period. Adjusted for stock-splits.

columns.name: Shares (Diluted)
columns.description: Shares outstanding adjusted for dilution from stock-options etc. Weighted average for the period. Adjusted for stock-splits.

columns.name: Source
columns.description: Link to source of the financial statement.

columns.name: Other Operating Income
columns.description:
Other operating income includes revenue from all other operating
activities which are not related to the principal activities of the
company.

columns.name: EBITDA
columns.description: EBITDA stands for earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. EBITDA is one indicator of a company's financial performance and is used as a proxy for the earning potential of a business.

columns.name: Total Debt
columns.description: Short term debt plus long term debt.

columns.name: Free Cash Flow
columns.description: Free cash flow (FCF) is a measure of a company's financial performance, calculated as operating cash flow minus capital expenditures. FCF represents the cash that a company is able to generate after spending the money required to maintain or expand its asset base. FCF is important because it allows a company to pursue opportunities that enhance shareholder value.

columns.name: Gross Profit Margin
columns.description: Gross margin is net sales less the cost of goods sold. The gross margin reveals the amount that an entity earns from the sale of its products and services, before the deduction of any selling and administrative expenses.

columns.name: Operating Margin
columns.description: In business, operating margin—also known as operating income margin, operating profit margin and return on sales (ROS)—is the ratio of operating income (operating profit in the UK) to net sales, usually presented in percent.

columns.name: Net Profit Margin
columns.description: Net profit margin is the percentage of revenue remaining after all operating expenses, interest, taxes and preferred stock dividends (but not common stock dividends) have been deducted from a company's total revenue.

columns.name: Return on Equity
columns.description: Return on equity (ROE) is the amount of net income returned as a percentage of shareholders equity. Return on equity measures a corporation's profitability by revealing how much profit a company generates with the money shareholders have invested.

columns.name: Return on Assets
columns.description: Return on assets (ROA) is an indicator of how profitable a company is relative to its total assets. ROA gives a manager, investor, or analyst an idea as to how efficient a company's management is at using its assets to generate earnings.

columns.name: Free Cash Flow to Net Income
columns.description: Free cash flow divided by net income for the period.

columns.name: Current Ratio
columns.description: The current ratio is a liquidity ratio that measures whether or not a firm has enough resources to meet its short-term obligations. It compares a firm's current assets to its current liabilities.

columns.name: Liabilities to Equity Ratio
columns.description: Calculated by dividing a company’s total liabilities by its stockholders' equity, is a debt ratio used to measure a company's financial leverage. The D/E ratio indicates how much debt a company is using to finance its assets relative to the value of shareholders’ equity.

columns.name: Debt Ratio
columns.description: The debt to total assets ratio is an indicator of financial leverage. It tells you the percentage of total assets that were financed by creditors, liabilities, debt.

columns.name: Earnings Per Share, Basic
columns.description: Basic earnings per share is the amount of a company’s profit or loss for a reporting period that is available to the shares of its common stock that are outstanding during the reporting period. It is a useful measure of performance for companies with simplified capital structures.

columns.name: Earnings Per Share, Diluted
columns.description: Diluted EPS is a performance metric used to gauge the quality of a company's earnings per share (EPS) if all convertible securities were exercised. Convertible securities are all outstanding convertible preferred shares, convertible debentures, stock options (primarily employee-based) and warrants. Unless the company has no additional potential shares outstanding, which is a relatively rare circumstance, the diluted EPS will always be lower than the simple EPS.

columns.name: Sales Per Share
columns.description: Sales per share is a ratio that computes the total revenue earned per share over a 12-month period. It is calculated by dividing total revenue earned in a fiscal year by the weighted average of shares outstanding for that fiscal year.

columns.name: Equity Per Share
columns.description: The book value per share formula is used to calculate the per share value of a company based on its equity available to common shareholders. The term book value is a company's assets minus its liabilities and is sometimes referred to as stockholder's equity, owner's equity, shareholder's equity, or simply equity.

columns.name: Free Cash Flow Per Share
columns.description: Free cash flow per share is a measure of how much cash per share a business generates after accounting for capital expenditures like equipment or buildings. Free cash flow is available to be used for expansion, dividends, debt reduction, or other purposes.

columns.name: Dividends Per Share
columns.description: Dividend per share (DPS) is the sum of declared dividends issued by a company for every ordinary share outstanding. Dividend per share (DPS) is the total dividends paid out by a business, including interim dividends, divided by the number of outstanding ordinary shares issued. A company's DPS is usually derived using the dividend paid in the most recent quarter, which is also used to calculate the dividend yield.

columns.name: Pietroski F-Score
columns.description: The score is calculated based on 9 criteria divided into 3 groups (Profitability, Leverage/Liquidity and Operating Efficiency), for each criteria that is passed, 1 point is added to the total score (ranges from 0 to 9); Return on Assets (1 point if it is positive in the current year, 0 otherwise); Operating Cash Flow (1 point if it is positive in the current year, 0 otherwise); Change in Return of Assets (ROA) (1 point if ROA is higher in the current year compared to the previous one, 0 otherwise); Accruals (1 point if Operating Cash Flow/Total Assets is higher than ROA in the current year, 0 otherwise); Change in Leverage (long-term) ratio (1 point if the ratio is lower this year compared to the previous one, 0 otherwise); Change in Current ratio (1 point if it is higher in the current year compared to the previous one, 0 otherwise); Change in the number of shares (1 point if no new shares were issued during the last year); Change in Gross Margin (1 point if it is higher in the current year compared to the previous one, 0 otherwise); Change in Asset Turnover ratio (1 point if it is higher in the current year compared to the previous one, 0 otherwise);

columns.name: Ticker
columns.description: Ticker for identifying a stock e.g. MSFT for Microsoft.

This is typically NOT the date that the financial report was made available to the public, see PUBLISH_DATE for that.

columns.name: Publish Date
columns.description: Date that a financial report was first made available to the public. It is possible that the financial report was later restated, in which case RESTATED_DATE will reflect that. Note that for US companies, the PUBLISH_DATE currently only uses the publication date of the Form 10-K and 10-Q for the annual and quarterly reports, and does not use the publication date of preliminary reports filed as Form 8-K. So it is possible that the information was actually made available prior to the PUBLISH_DATE in such a preliminary report.

columns.name: Restated Date
columns.description: Date when a financial report was last restated. It is possible that a financial report has been restated multiple times, in which case this is the most recent date that it was restated, and the financial data will be from the latest restatement of the financial report. If the report was never restated, then this date will be the same as PUBLISH_DATE.

columns.name: EBITDA
columns.description: EBITDA stands for earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. EBITDA is one indicator of a company's financial performance and is used as a proxy for the earning potential of a business.

columns.name: Total Debt
columns.description: Short term debt plus long term debt.

columns.name: Free Cash Flow
columns.description: Free cash flow (FCF) is a measure of a company's financial performance, calculated as operating cash flow minus capital expenditures. FCF represents the cash that a company is able to generate after spending the money required to maintain or expand its asset base. FCF is important because it allows a company to pursue opportunities that enhance shareholder value.

columns.name: Gross Profit Margin
columns.description: Gross margin is net sales less the cost of goods sold. The gross margin reveals the amount that an entity earns from the sale of its products and services, before the deduction of any selling and administrative expenses.

columns.name: Operating Margin
columns.description: In business, operating margin—also known as operating income margin, operating profit margin and return on sales (ROS)—is the ratio of operating income (operating profit in the UK) to net sales, usually presented in percent.

columns.name: Net Profit Margin
columns.description: Net profit margin is the percentage of revenue remaining after all operating expenses, interest, taxes and preferred stock dividends (but not common stock dividends) have been deducted from a company's total revenue.

columns.name: Return on Equity
columns.description: Return on equity (ROE) is the amount of net income returned as a percentage of shareholders equity. Return on equity measures a corporation's profitability by revealing how much profit a company generates with the money shareholders have invested.

columns.name: Return on Assets
columns.description: Return on assets (ROA) is an indicator of how profitable a company is relative to its total assets. ROA gives a manager, investor, or analyst an idea as to how efficient a company's management is at using its assets to generate earnings.

columns.name: Free Cash Flow to Net Income
columns.description: Free cash flow divided by net income for the period.

columns.name: Current Ratio
columns.description: The current ratio is a liquidity ratio that measures whether or not a firm has enough resources to meet its short-term obligations. It compares a firm's current assets to its current liabilities.

columns.name: Liabilities to Equity Ratio
columns.description: Calculated by dividing a company’s total liabilities by its stockholders' equity, is a debt ratio used to measure a company's financial leverage. The D/E ratio indicates how much debt a company is using to finance its assets relative to the value of shareholders’ equity.

columns.name: Debt Ratio
columns.description: The debt to total assets ratio is an indicator of financial leverage. It tells you the percentage of total assets that were financed by creditors, liabilities, debt.

columns.name: Earnings Per Share, Basic
columns.description: Basic earnings per share is the amount of a company’s profit or loss for a reporting period that is available to the shares of its common stock that are outstanding during the reporting period. It is a useful measure of performance for companies with simplified capital structures.

columns.name: Earnings Per Share, Diluted
columns.description: Diluted EPS is a performance metric used to gauge the quality of a company's earnings per share (EPS) if all convertible securities were exercised. Convertible securities are all outstanding convertible preferred shares, convertible debentures, stock options (primarily employee-based) and warrants. Unless the company has no additional potential shares outstanding, which is a relatively rare circumstance, the diluted EPS will always be lower than the simple EPS.

columns.name: Sales Per Share
columns.description: Sales per share is a ratio that computes the total revenue earned per share over a 12-month period. It is calculated by dividing total revenue earned in a fiscal year by the weighted average of shares outstanding for that fiscal year.

columns.name: Equity Per Share
columns.description: The book value per share formula is used to calculate the per share value of a company based on its equity available to common shareholders. The term book value is a company's assets minus its liabilities and is sometimes referred to as stockholder's equity, owner's equity, shareholder's equity, or simply equity.

columns.name: Free Cash Flow Per Share
columns.description: Free cash flow per share is a measure of how much cash per share a business generates after accounting for capital expenditures like equipment or buildings. Free cash flow is available to be used for expansion, dividends, debt reduction, or other purposes.

columns.name: Dividends Per Share
columns.description: Dividend per share (DPS) is the sum of declared dividends issued by a company for every ordinary share outstanding. Dividend per share (DPS) is the total dividends paid out by a business, including interim dividends, divided by the number of outstanding ordinary shares issued. A company's DPS is usually derived using the dividend paid in the most recent quarter, which is also used to calculate the dividend yield.

columns.name: Pietroski F-Score
columns.description: The score is calculated based on 9 criteria divided into 3 groups (Profitability, Leverage/Liquidity and Operating Efficiency), for each criteria that is passed, 1 point is added to the total score (ranges from 0 to 9); Return on Assets (1 point if it is positive in the current year, 0 otherwise); Operating Cash Flow (1 point if it is positive in the current year, 0 otherwise); Change in Return of Assets (ROA) (1 point if ROA is higher in the current year compared to the previous one, 0 otherwise); Accruals (1 point if Operating Cash Flow/Total Assets is higher than ROA in the current year, 0 otherwise); Change in Leverage (long-term) ratio (1 point if the ratio is lower this year compared to the previous one, 0 otherwise); Change in Current ratio (1 point if it is higher in the current year compared to the previous one, 0 otherwise); Change in the number of shares (1 point if no new shares were issued during the last year); Change in Gross Margin (1 point if it is higher in the current year compared to the previous one, 0 otherwise); Change in Asset Turnover ratio (1 point if it is higher in the current year compared to the previous one, 0 otherwise);

columns.name: Ticker
columns.description: Ticker for identifying a stock e.g. MSFT for Microsoft.

columns.name: SimFinId
columns.description: Unique ID for a company in the SimFin database. This is the number that is shown at the end of the URL if you visit a company profile on simfin.com

columns.name: Currency
columns.description: Currency for the data e.g. 'USD' for U.S. Dollar.

columns.name: Fiscal Year
columns.description: Fiscal year for a financial report. This may not equal the calendar year.

columns.name: Fiscal Period
columns.description: Fiscal period for a financial report e.g. 'Q1' for the 1st Quarter.

columns.name: Report Date
columns.description: Date that is stated in the financial report. For example, a date of 2018-12-31 means that the financial report is for the annual or quarterly period ending on that date. This is typically NOT the date that the financial report was made available to the public, see PUBLISH_DATE for that.

columns.name: Publish Date
columns.description: Date that a financial report was first made available to the public. It is possible that the financial report was later restated, in which case RESTATED_DATE will reflect that. Note that for US companies, the PUBLISH_DATE currently only uses the publication date of the Form 10-K and 10-Q for the annual and quarterly reports, and does not use the publication date of preliminary reports filed as Form 8-K. So it is possible that the information was actually made available prior to the PUBLISH_DATE in such a preliminary report.

columns.name: Restated Date
columns.description: Date when a financial report was last restated. It is possible that a financial report has been restated multiple times, in which case this is the most recent date that it was restated, and the financial data will be from the latest restatement of the financial report. If the report was never restated, then this date will be the same as PUBLISH_DATE.

columns.description: EBITDA stands for earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. EBITDA is one indicator of a company's financial performance and is used as a proxy for the earning potential of a business.

columns.name: Total Debt
columns.description: Short term debt plus long term debt.

FCF represents the cash that a company is able to generate after spending the money required to maintain or expand its asset base. FCF is important because it allows a company to pursue opportunities that enhance shareholder value.

columns.name: Debt Ratio

columns.name: Earnings Per Share, Basic
columns.description: Basic earnings per share is the amount of a company’s profit or loss for a reporting period that is available to the shares of its common stock that are outstanding during the reporting period. It is a useful measure of performance for companies with simplified capital structures.

columns.name: Earnings Per Share, Diluted
columns.description: Diluted EPS is a performance metric used to gauge the quality of a company's earnings per share (EPS) if all convertible securities were exercised. Convertible securities are all outstanding convertible preferred shares, convertible debentures, stock options (primarily employee-based) and warrants. Unless the company has no additional potential shares outstanding, which is a relatively rare circumstance, the diluted EPS will always be lower than the simple EPS.

columns.name: Sales Per Share
columns.description: Sales per share is a ratio that computes the total revenue earned per share over a 12-month period. It is calculated by dividing total revenue earned in a fiscal year by the weighted average of shares outstanding for that fiscal year.

columns.name: Equity Per Share
columns.description: The book value per share formula is used to calculate the per share value of a company based on its equity available to common shareholders. The term book value is a company's assets minus its liabilities and is sometimes referred to as stockholder's equity, owner's equity, shareholder's equity, or simply equity.

columns.name: Free Cash Flow Per Share
columns.description: Free cash flow per share is a measure of how much cash per share a business generates after accounting for capital expenditures like equipment or buildings. Free cash flow is available to be used for expansion, dividends, debt reduction, or other purposes.

columns.name: Dividends Per Share
columns.description: Dividend per share (DPS) is the sum of declared dividends issued by a company for every ordinary share outstanding. Dividend per share (DPS) is the total dividends paid out by a business, including interim dividends, divided by the number of outstanding ordinary shares issued. A company's DPS is usually derived using the dividend paid in the most recent quarter, which is also used to calculate the dividend yield.

columns.name: Pietroski F-Score
columns.description: The score is calculated based on 9 criteria divided into 3 groups (Profitability, Leverage/Liquidity and Operating Efficiency), for each criteria that is passed, 1 point is added to the total score (ranges from 0 to 9); Return on Assets (1 point if it is positive in the current year, 0 otherwise); Operating Cash Flow (1 point if it is positive in the current year, 0 otherwise); Change in Return of Assets (ROA) (1 point if ROA is higher in the current year compared to the previous one, 0 otherwise); Accruals (1 point if Operating Cash Flow/Total Assets is higher than ROA in the current year, 0 otherwise); Change in Leverage (long-term) ratio (1 point if the ratio is lower this year compared to the previous one, 0 otherwise); Change in Current ratio (1 point if it is higher in the current year compared to the previous one, 0 otherwise); Change in the number of shares (1 point if no new shares were issued during the last year); Change in Gross Margin (1 point if it is higher in the current year compared to the previous one, 0 otherwise); Change in Asset Turnover ratio (1 point if it is higher in the current year compared to the previous one, 0 otherwise);

columns.name: Ticker
columns.description: Ticker for identifying a stock e.g. MSFT for Microsoft.

columns.name: SimFinId
columns.description: Unique ID for a company in the SimFin database. This is the number that is shown at the end of the URL if you visit a company profile on simfin.com

columns.name: Date
columns.description: Date associated with the given data e.g. share-prices.

columns.name: Open
columns.description: Daily share-price open. Adjusted for stock-splits but NOT dividends.

columns.name: Low
columns.description: Daily share-price low. Adjusted for stock-splits but NOT dividends.

columns.name: High
columns.description: Daily share-price high. Adjusted for stock-splits but NOT dividends.

columns.name: Close
columns.description: Daily share-price close. Adjusted for stock-splits but NOT dividends. This is used as the default share-price.

columns.name: Adj. Close
columns.description: Daily share-price close adjusted for BOTH stock-splits AND dividends aka. Total Return.
columns.description_long: Daily share-price close adjusted for BOTH stock-splits AND dividends, so dividends are reinvested back into the stock immediately, taxes are ignored. This is also known as the Total Return and is used to calculate stock-returns especially over longer time-periods where reinvestment of dividends can be a significant contribution to the overall return on a stock. This should NOT be used to calculate ratios such as P/E and P/Sales or technical indicators such as moving averages. Use SHARE_PRICE_CLOSE for that.

columns.name: Dividend
columns.description: Dividends paid per share, before taxes. Adjusted for stock-splits.

columns.name: Volume
columns.description: Number of shares traded during the day. Adjusted for stock-splits.

columns.name: Shares Outstanding
columns.description: Number of common shares outstanding as per the last reported date.

columns.name: Ticker
columns.description: Ticker for identifying a stock e.g. MSFT for Microsoft.

columns.name: SimFinId
columns.description: Unique ID for a company in the SimFin database. This is the number that is shown at the end of the URL if you visit a company profile on simfin.com

columns.name: Date
columns.description: Date associated with the given data e.g. share-prices.

columns.name: Market-Cap
columns.description: Common shares outstanding times closing price (adjusted for stock splits).

columns.name: Price to Earnings Ratio (quarterly)
columns.description: The price-earnings ratio (P/E ratio) is the ratio for valuing a company that measures its current share price relative to its per-share earnings. The price-earnings ratio is also sometimes known as the price multiple or the earnings multiple.

columns.name: Price to Earnings Ratio (ttm)
columns.description: The price-earnings ratio (P/E ratio) is the ratio for valuing a company that measures its current share price relative to its per-share earnings. The price-earnings ratio is also sometimes known as the price multiple or the earnings multiple.

columns.name: Price to Sales Ratio (quarterly)
columns.description: A valuation ratio that compares a company’s stock price to its revenues. The price-to-sales ratio is an indicator of the value placed on each dollar of a company’s sales or revenues. It can be calculated either by dividing the company’s market capitalization by its total sales over a 12-month period, or on a per-share basis by dividing the stock price by sales per share for a 12-month period. Like all ratios, the price-to-sales ratio is most relevant when used to compare companies in the same sector. A low ratio may indicate possible undervaluation, while a ratio that is significantly above the average may suggest overvaluation. Abbreviated as the P/S ratio or PSR, this ratio is also known as a sales multiple or revenue multiple.

columns.name: Price to Sales Ratio (ttm)
columns.description: A valuation ratio that compares a company’s stock price to its revenues. The price-to-sales ratio is an indicator of the value placed on each dollar of a company’s sales or revenues. It can be calculated either by dividing the company’s market capitalization by its total sales over a 12-month period, or on a per-share basis by dividing the stock price by sales per share for a 12-month period. Like all ratios, the price-to-sales ratio is most relevant when used to compare companies in the same sector. A low ratio may indicate possible undervaluation, while a ratio that is significantly above the average may suggest overvaluation. Abbreviated as the P/S ratio or PSR, this ratio is also known as a sales multiple or revenue multiple.

columns.name: Price to Book Value
columns.description: The price-to-book ratio (P/B Ratio) is a ratio used to compare a stock's market value to its book value. It is calculated by dividing the current closing price of the stock by the latest quarter's book value per share.

columns.name: Price to Free Cash Flow (quarterly)
columns.description: The price-to-cash-flow ratio is the ratio of a stock’s price to its cash flow per share. The price-to-cash-flow ratio is an indicator of a stock’s valuation. Although there is no single figure to indicate an optimal price-to-cash-flow ratio, a ratio in the low single digits may indicate the stock is undervalued, while a higher ratio may suggest potential overvaluation. The ratio takes into consideration a stock’s operating cash flow, which adds non-cash earnings such as depreciation and amortization to net income. It is especially useful for valuing stocks that have positive cash flow but are not profitable because of large non-cash charges.

columns.name: Price to Free Cash Flow (ttm)
columns.description: The price-to-cash-flow ratio is the ratio of a stock’s price to its cash flow per share. The price-to-cash-flow ratio is an indicator of a stock’s valuation. Although there is no single figure to indicate an optimal price-to-cash-flow ratio, a ratio in the low single digits may indicate the stock is undervalued, while a higher ratio may suggest potential overvaluation. The ratio takes into consideration a stock’s operating cash flow, which adds non-cash earnings such as depreciation and amortization to net income. It is especially useful for valuing stocks that have positive cash flow but are not profitable because of large non-cash charges.

columns.name: Enterprise Value
columns.description: Enterprise Value, or EV for short, is a measure of a company's total value, often used as a more comprehensive alternative to equity market capitalization. Enterprise value is calculated as the market capitalization plus debt, minority interest and preferred shares, minus total cash and cash equivalents.

columns.name: EV/EBITDA
columns.description: Enterprise value/EBITDA (more commonly referred to by the acronym EV/EBITDA) is a popular valuation multiple used in the finance industry to measure the value of a company. It is the most widely used valuation multiple based on enterprise value and is often used in conjunction with, or as an alternative to, the P/E ratio (Price/Earnings ratio) to determine the fair market value of a company.

columns.name: EV/Sales
columns.description: Enterprise-value-to-sales is a valuation measure that compares the enterprise value (EV) of a company to the company's sales. EV-to-sales gives investors a quantifiable metric of how much it costs to purchase the company's sales. This measure is an expansion of the price-to-sales (P/S) valuation, which uses market capitalization instead of enterprise value.

columns.name: EV/FCF
columns.description: Enterprise value divided by free cash flow

columns.name: Book to Market Value
columns.description: Book value of equity divided by market capitalisation.

columns.name: Operating Income/EV
columns.description: Operating income divided by enterprise value

columns.name: IndustryId
columns.description: Industry code of company. See 'industries' dataset for details.

columns.name: Sector
columns.description: Sector associated with IndustryId.

columns.name: Industry
columns.description: Industry associated with IndustryId.

columns.name: MarketId
columns.description: Market ID

columns.name: Market Name
columns.description: Name of market associated with MarketId

columns.name: Currency
columns.description: Currency for the data e.g. 'USD' for U.S. Dollar.
